segment.source: You can use the PropertyPath class and the string syntax to instantiate a PropertyPath value either in XAML or in code.
segment.target: You can use the PropertyPath class and the string syntax to instantiate a PropertyPath value either in XAML or in code.

segment.source: Property-path syntax'
segment.target: Property-path syntax'

segment.source: Property-path syntax
segment.target: Property-path syntax

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You can use the PropertyPath class and the string syntax to instantiate a PropertyPath value either in XAML or in code.
segment.target: You can use the PropertyPath class and the string syntax to instantiate a PropertyPath value either in XAML or in code.

segment.source: PropertyPath values are used by data binding.
segment.target: PropertyPath values are used by data binding.

segment.source: A similar syntax is used for targeting storyboarded animations.
segment.target: A similar syntax is used for targeting storyboarded animations.

segment.source: But animation targeting doesn't create underlying Property-path syntax values, it keeps the info as a string.
segment.target: But animation targeting doesn't create underlying Property-path syntax values, it keeps the info as a string.

segment.source: For both scenarios, a property path describes a traversal of one or more object-property relationships that eventually resolve to a single property.
segment.target: For both scenarios, a property path describes a traversal of one or more object-property relationships that eventually resolve to a single property.

segment.source: You can set a property path string directly to an attribute in XAML.
segment.target: You can set a property path string directly to an attribute in XAML.

segment.source: You can use the same string syntax to construct a PropertyPath that sets a Binding in code, or to set an animation target in code using SetTargetProperty.
segment.target: You can use the same string syntax to construct a PropertyPath that sets a Binding in code, or to set an animation target in code using SetTargetProperty.

segment.source: There are two distinct feature areas in the Windows Runtime that use a property path: data binding, and animation targeting.
segment.target: There are two distinct feature areas in the Windows Runtime that use a property path: data binding, and animation targeting.

segment.source: Animation targeting doesn't create underlying Property-path syntax values in the Windows Runtime implementation, it keeps the info as a string, but the concepts of object-property traversal are very similar.
segment.target: Animation targeting doesn't create underlying Property-path syntax values in the Windows Runtime implementation, it keeps the info as a string, but the concepts of object-property traversal are very similar.

segment.source: Data binding and animation targeting each evaluate a property path slightly differently, so we describe property path syntax separately for each.
segment.target: Data binding and animation targeting each evaluate a property path slightly differently, so we describe property path syntax separately for each.

segment.source: Property path for objects in data binding
segment.target: Property path for objects in data binding

segment.source: In Windows Runtime, you can bind to the target value of any dependency property.
segment.target: In Windows Runtime, you can bind to the target value of any dependency property.

segment.source: The source property value for a data binding doesn't have to be a dependency property; it can be a property on a business object (for example a class written in a Microsoft .NET language or C++).
segment.target: The source property value for a data binding doesn't have to be a dependency property; it can be a property on a business object (for example a class written in a Microsoft .NET language or C++).

segment.source: Or, the source object for the binding value can be an existing dependency object already defined by the app.
segment.target: Or, the source object for the binding value can be an existing dependency object already defined by the app.

segment.source: The source can be referenced either by a simple property name, or by a traversal of the object-property relationships in the object graph of the business object.
segment.target: The source can be referenced either by a simple property name, or by a traversal of the object-property relationships in the object graph of the business object.

segment.source: You can bind to an individual property value, or you can bind to a target property that holds lists or collections.
segment.target: You can bind to an individual property value, or you can bind to a target property that holds lists or collections.

segment.source: If your source is a collection, or if the path specifies a collection property, the data-binding engine matches the collection items of the source to the binding target, resulting in behavior such as populating a ListBox with a list of items from a data source collection without needing to anticipate the specific items in that collection.
segment.target: If your source is a collection, or if the path specifies a collection property, the data-binding engine matches the collection items of the source to the binding target, resulting in behavior such as populating a ListBox with a list of items from a data source collection without needing to anticipate the specific items in that collection.

segment.source: Traversing an object graph
segment.target: Traversing an object graph

segment.source: The element of the syntax that denotes the traversal of an object-property relationship in an object graph is the dot (.) character.
segment.target: The element of the syntax that denotes the traversal of an object-property relationship in an object graph is the dot (.) character.

segment.source: Each dot in a property path string indicates a division between an object (left side of the dot) and a property of that object (right side of the dot).
segment.target: Each dot in a property path string indicates a division between an object (left side of the dot) and a property of that object (right side of the dot).

segment.source: The string is evaluated left-to-right, which enables stepping through multiple object-property relationships.
segment.target: The string is evaluated left-to-right, which enables stepping through multiple object-property relationships.

segment.source: Let's look at an example:
segment.target: Let's look at an example:

segment.source: Here's how this path is evaluated:
segment.target: Here's how this path is evaluated:

segment.source: The data context object (or a Source specified by the same Binding) is searched for a property named "Customer".
segment.target: The data context object (or a Source specified by the same Binding) is searched for a property named "Customer".

segment.source: The object that is the value of the "Customer" property is searched for a property named "Address".
segment.target: The object that is the value of the "Customer" property is searched for a property named "Address".

segment.source: The object that is the value of the "Address" property is searched for a property named "StreetAddress1".
segment.target: The object that is the value of the "Address" property is searched for a property named "StreetAddress1".

segment.source: At each of these steps, the value is treated as an object.
segment.target: At each of these steps, the value is treated as an object.

segment.source: The type of the result is checked only when the binding is applied to a specific property.
segment.target: The type of the result is checked only when the binding is applied to a specific property.

segment.source: This example would fail if "Address" were just a string value that didn't expose what part of the string was the street address.
segment.target: This example would fail if "Address" were just a string value that didn't expose what part of the string was the street address.

segment.source: Typically, the binding is pointing to the specific nested property values of a business object that has a known and deliberate information structure.
segment.target: Typically, the binding is pointing to the specific nested property values of a business object that has a known and deliberate information structure.

segment.source: Rules for the properties in a data-binding property path
segment.target: Rules for the properties in a data-binding property path

segment.source: All properties referenced by a property path must be public in the source business object.
segment.target: All properties referenced by a property path must be public in the source business object.

segment.source: The end property (the property that is the last named property in the path) must be public and must be mutable – you can't bind to static values.
segment.target: The end property (the property that is the last named property in the path) must be public and must be mutable – you can't bind to static values.

segment.source: The end property must be read/write if this path is used as the Path information for a two-way binding.
segment.target: The end property must be read/write if this path is used as the Path information for a two-way binding.

segment.source: Indexers
segment.target: Indexers

segment.source: A property path for data-binding can include references to indexed properties.
segment.target: A property path for data-binding can include references to indexed properties.

segment.source: This enables binding to ordered lists/vectors, or to dictionaries/maps.
segment.target: This enables binding to ordered lists/vectors, or to dictionaries/maps.

segment.source: Use square brackets "\[\]" characters to indicate an indexed property.
segment.target: Use square brackets "\[\]" characters to indicate an indexed property.

segment.source: The contents of these brackets can be either an integer (for ordered list) or an unquoted string (for dictionaries).
segment.target: The contents of these brackets can be either an integer (for ordered list) or an unquoted string (for dictionaries).

segment.source: You can also bind to a dictionary where the key is an integer.
segment.target: You can also bind to a dictionary where the key is an integer.

segment.source: You can use different indexed properties in the same path with a dot separating the object-property.
segment.target: You can use different indexed properties in the same path with a dot separating the object-property.

segment.source: For example, consider a business object where there is a list of "Teams" (ordered list), each of which has a dictionary of "Players" where each player is keyed by last name.
segment.target: For example, consider a business object where there is a list of "Teams" (ordered list), each of which has a dictionary of "Players" where each player is keyed by last name.

segment.source: An example property path to a specific player on the second team is: "Teams\[1\].Players\[Smith\]".
segment.target: An example property path to a specific player on the second team is: "Teams\[1\].Players\[Smith\]".

segment.source: (You use 1 to indicate the second item in "Teams" because the list is zero-indexed.)
segment.target: (You use 1 to indicate the second item in "Teams" because the list is zero-indexed.)

segment.source: Note Indexing support for C++ data sources is limited; see Data binding in depth.
segment.target: Note Indexing support for C++ data sources is limited; see Data binding in depth.

segment.source: Attached properties
segment.target: Attached properties

segment.source: Property paths can include references to attached properties.
segment.target: Property paths can include references to attached properties.

segment.source: Because the identifying name of an attached property already includes a dot, you must enclose any attached property name within parentheses so that the dot isn't treated as an object-property step.
segment.target: Because the identifying name of an attached property already includes a dot, you must enclose any attached property name within parentheses so that the dot isn't treated as an object-property step.

segment.source: For example, the string to specify that you want to use Canvas.ZIndex as a binding path is "(Canvas.ZIndex)".
segment.target: For example, the string to specify that you want to use Canvas.ZIndex as a binding path is "(Canvas.ZIndex)".

segment.source: For more info on attached properties see Attached properties overview.
segment.target: For more info on attached properties see Attached properties overview.

segment.source: Combining property path syntax
segment.target: Combining property path syntax

segment.source: You can combine various elements of property path syntax in a single string.
segment.target: You can combine various elements of property path syntax in a single string.

segment.source: For example, you can define a property path that references an indexed attached property, if your data source had such a property.
segment.target: For example, you can define a property path that references an indexed attached property, if your data source had such a property.

segment.source: Debugging a binding property path
segment.target: Debugging a binding property path

segment.source: Because a property path is interpreted by a binding engine and relies on info that may be present only at run-time, you must often debug a property path for binding without being able to rely on conventional design-time or compile-time support in the development tools.
segment.target: Because a property path is interpreted by a binding engine and relies on info that may be present only at run-time, you must often debug a property path for binding without being able to rely on conventional design-time or compile-time support in the development tools.

segment.source: In many cases the run-time result of failing to resolve a property path is a blank value with no error, because that is the by-design fallback behavior of binding resolution.
segment.target: In many cases the run-time result of failing to resolve a property path is a blank value with no error, because that is the by-design fallback behavior of binding resolution.

segment.source: Fortunately, Microsoft Visual Studio provides a debug output mode that can isolate which part of a property path that's specifying a binding source failed to resolve.
segment.target: Fortunately, Microsoft Visual Studio provides a debug output mode that can isolate which part of a property path that's specifying a binding source failed to resolve.

segment.source: For more info on using this development tool feature, see "Debugging" section of Data binding in depth.
segment.target: For more info on using this development tool feature, see "Debugging" section of Data binding in depth.

segment.source: Property path for animation targeting
segment.target: Property path for animation targeting

segment.source: Animations rely on targeting a dependency property where storyboarded values are applied when the animation runs.
segment.target: Animations rely on targeting a dependency property where storyboarded values are applied when the animation runs.

segment.source: To identify the object where the property to be animated exists, the animation targets an element by name (x:Name attribute).
segment.target: To identify the object where the property to be animated exists, the animation targets an element by name (x:Name attribute).

segment.source: It is often necessary to define a property path that starts with the object identified as the Storyboard.TargetName, and ends with the particular dependency property value where the animation should apply.
segment.target: It is often necessary to define a property path that starts with the object identified as the Storyboard.TargetName, and ends with the particular dependency property value where the animation should apply.

segment.source: That property path is used as the value for Storyboard.TargetProperty.
segment.target: That property path is used as the value for Storyboard.TargetProperty.

segment.source: For more info on the how to define animations in XAML, see Storyboarded animations.
segment.target: For more info on the how to define animations in XAML, see Storyboarded animations.

segment.source: Simple targeting
segment.target: Simple targeting

segment.source: If you are animating a property that exists on the targeted object itself, and that property's type can have an animation applied directly to it (rather than to a sub-property of a property's value) then you can simply name the property being animated without any further qualification.
segment.target: If you are animating a property that exists on the targeted object itself, and that property's type can have an animation applied directly to it (rather than to a sub-property of a property's value) then you can simply name the property being animated without any further qualification.

segment.source: For example, if you are targeting a Shape subclass such as Rectangle, and you are applying an animated Color to the Fill property, your property path can be "Fill".
segment.target: For example, if you are targeting a Shape subclass such as Rectangle, and you are applying an animated Color to the Fill property, your property path can be "Fill".

segment.source: Indirect property targeting
segment.target: Indirect property targeting

segment.source: You can animate a property that is a sub-property of the target object.
segment.target: You can animate a property that is a sub-property of the target object.

segment.source: In other words, if there's a property of the target object that's an object itself, and that object has properties, you must define a property path that explains how to step through that object-property relationship.
segment.target: In other words, if there's a property of the target object that's an object itself, and that object has properties, you must define a property path that explains how to step through that object-property relationship.

segment.source: Whenever you are specifying an object where you want to animate a sub-property, you enclose the property name in parentheses, and you specify the property in typename.propertyname format.
segment.target: Whenever you are specifying an object where you want to animate a sub-property, you enclose the property name in parentheses, and you specify the property in typename.propertyname format.

segment.source: For example, to specify that you want the object value of a target object's RenderTransform property, you specify "(UIElement.RenderTransform)" as the first step in the property path.
segment.target: For example, to specify that you want the object value of a target object's RenderTransform property, you specify "(UIElement.RenderTransform)" as the first step in the property path.

segment.source: This isn't yet a complete path, because there are no animations that can apply to a Transform value directly.
segment.target: This isn't yet a complete path, because there are no animations that can apply to a Transform value directly.

segment.source: So for this example, you now complete the property path so that the end property is a property of a Transform subclass that can be animated by a Double value: "(UIElement.RenderTransform).(CompositeTransform.TranslateX)"
segment.target: So for this example, you now complete the property path so that the end property is a property of a Transform subclass that can be animated by a Double value: "(UIElement.RenderTransform).(CompositeTransform.TranslateX)"

segment.source: Specifying a particular child in a collection
segment.target: Specifying a particular child in a collection

segment.source: To specify a child item in a collection property, you can use a numeric indexer.
segment.target: To specify a child item in a collection property, you can use a numeric indexer.

segment.source: Use square brackets "\[\]" characters around the integer index value.
segment.target: Use square brackets "\[\]" characters around the integer index value.

segment.source: You can reference only ordered lists, not dictionaries.
segment.target: You can reference only ordered lists, not dictionaries.

segment.source: Because a collection isn't a value that can be animated, an indexer usage can never be the end property in a property path.
segment.target: Because a collection isn't a value that can be animated, an indexer usage can never be the end property in a property path.

segment.source: For example, to specify that you want to animate the first color stop color in a LinearGradientBrush that is applied to a control's Background property, this is the property path: "(Control.Background).(GradientBrush.GradientStops)\[0\].(GradientStop.Color)".
segment.target: For example, to specify that you want to animate the first color stop color in a LinearGradientBrush that is applied to a control's Background property, this is the property path: "(Control.Background).(GradientBrush.GradientStops)\[0\].(GradientStop.Color)".

segment.source: Note how the indexer is not the last step in the path, and that the last step particularly must reference the GradientStop.Color property of item 0 in the collection to apply a Color animated value to it.
segment.target: Note how the indexer is not the last step in the path, and that the last step particularly must reference the GradientStop.Color property of item 0 in the collection to apply a Color animated value to it.

segment.source: Animating an attached property
segment.target: Animating an attached property

segment.source: It isn't a common scenario, but it is possible to animate an attached property, so long as that attached property has a property value that matches an animation type.
segment.target: It isn't a common scenario, but it is possible to animate an attached property, so long as that attached property has a property value that matches an animation type.

segment.source: Because the identifying name of an attached property already includes a dot, you must enclose any attached property name within parentheses so that the dot isn't treated as an object-property step.
segment.target: Because the identifying name of an attached property already includes a dot, you must enclose any attached property name within parentheses so that the dot isn't treated as an object-property step.

segment.source: For example, the string to specify that you want to animate the Grid.Row attached property on an object, use the property path "(Grid.Row)".
segment.target: For example, the string to specify that you want to animate the Grid.Row attached property on an object, use the property path "(Grid.Row)".

segment.source: Note For this example, the value of Grid.Row is an Int32 property type.
segment.target: Note For this example, the value of Grid.Row is an Int32 property type.

segment.source: so you can't animate it with a Double animation.
segment.target: so you can't animate it with a Double animation.

segment.source: Instead, you'd define an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames that has DiscreteObjectKeyFrame components, where the ObjectKeyFrame.Value is set to an integer such as "0" or "1".
segment.target: Instead, you'd define an ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames that has DiscreteObjectKeyFrame components, where the ObjectKeyFrame.Value is set to an integer such as "0" or "1".

segment.source: Rules for the properties in an animation targeting property path
segment.target: Rules for the properties in an animation targeting property path

segment.source: The assumed starting point of the property path is the object identified by a Storyboard.TargetName.
segment.target: The assumed starting point of the property path is the object identified by a Storyboard.TargetName.

segment.source: All objects and properties referenced along the property path must be public.
segment.target: All objects and properties referenced along the property path must be public.

segment.source: The end property (the property that is the last named property in the path) must be public, be read-write, and be a dependency property.
segment.target: The end property (the property that is the last named property in the path) must be public, be read-write, and be a dependency property.

segment.source: The end property must have a property type that is able to be animated by one of the broad classes of animation types (Color animations, Double animations, Point animations, ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames).
segment.target: The end property must have a property type that is able to be animated by one of the broad classes of animation types (Color animations, Double animations, Point animations, ObjectAnimationUsingKeyFrames).

segment.source: The PropertyPath class
segment.target: The PropertyPath class

segment.source: The PropertyPath class is the underlying property type of Binding.Path for the binding scenario.
segment.target: The PropertyPath class is the underlying property type of Binding.Path for the binding scenario.

segment.source: Most of the time, you can apply a PropertyPath in XAML without using any code at all.
segment.target: Most of the time, you can apply a PropertyPath in XAML without using any code at all.

segment.source: But in some cases you may want to define a PropertyPath object using code and assign it to a property at run-time.
segment.target: But in some cases you may want to define a PropertyPath object using code and assign it to a property at run-time.

segment.source: PropertyPath has a PropertyPath(String) constructor, and doesn't have a default constructor.
segment.target: PropertyPath has a PropertyPath(String) constructor, and doesn't have a default constructor.

segment.source: The string you pass to this constructor is a string that's defined using the property path syntax as we explained earlier.
segment.target: The string you pass to this constructor is a string that's defined using the property path syntax as we explained earlier.

segment.source: This is also the same string you'd use to assign Path as a XAML attribute.
segment.target: This is also the same string you'd use to assign Path as a XAML attribute.

segment.source: The only other API of the PropertyPath class is the Path property, which is read-only.
segment.target: The only other API of the PropertyPath class is the Path property, which is read-only.

segment.source: You could use this property as the construction string for another PropertyPath instance.
segment.target: You could use this property as the construction string for another PropertyPath instance.

segment.target: Related topics
